source:
have you ever panicked about whether you locked the front door , been woken by a facebook notification or desperately needed a phone charger ?
to deal with these sorts of everyday emergencies , one company has designed a range of prototype products .
you can vote on which one is your favourite - and the winner will be made into an actual product , funded through a kickstarter campaign .
leeds-based direct line is running a competition called #everydayfix .
they asked groups to design products to deal with common problems .
these include forgetting to lock the door , which one company hopes to solve with their forget me lock prototype , shown
the products were designed as part of the direct line everyday fix design makeathon .
they asked people to pick their top ten ` everyday emergencies ' - things that caused them an undue amount of stress in their daily lives .
groups from london-based design company makerversity were then asked to design products that could alleviate certain emergencies - and three were picked for a shortlist .
not being able to sleep ( 46 per cent * )
losing your keys ( 37 per cent )
being stuck in traffic when already late ( 35 per cent )
losing an important paper or document ( 33 per cent )
nowhere to park ( 32 per cent )
printer not working when you need to print something ( 31 per cent )
running out of battery on your phone whilst out ( 31 per cent )
discovering you are out of toilet roll whilst on the loo ( 30 per cent )
dealing with machine operated customer service ( 26 per cent )
forgetting your bank card when paying for an item ( 25 per cent )
* how many people thought this was a problem
in the survey of 2,000 people , the top emergency was not being able to sleep .
so a group called instruments designed a product called ` snooze ' , an alarm clock which connects with your phone and silences any notifications to ensure a good night 's sleep .
to deal with not remembering if you had locked your door , onn studio created the forget me lock - a device to reassure you that you have locked the front door .
it fastens on the key and swivels green to show the door is open , and red to signify it 's locked .
this means that even when out or about , you can find out if your door is locked or not .
another group designed nipper - the world 's smallest mobile phone charger according to its creators , impulse .
any household battery can be used as its energy source , with two terminals attaching either side and then connecting to your phone to provide a boost .
direct line is running a competition on twitter where you can vote for your favourite of these three products by retweeting tweets about snooze , forget me lock or nipper .
the forget me lock is coloured green and red and fastens on a key .
when the key is turned in a lock it swivels green to show the door is open , and red to signify it 's locked .
another group designed nipper - the world 's smallest mobile phone charger according to its creators , impulse .
any household battery can be used as its energy source , with two terminals attaching either side and then connecting to your phone to provide a boost
the nipper device ( shown ) is designed to help people who run out of battery while they are out and about
in the survey of 2,000 people , the top emergency was not being able to sleep .
so a group called instruments designed a product called snooze , shown , an alarm clock which connects with your phone and silences any notifications to ensure a good night 's sleep
whichever tweet has the most retweets , with the #everydayfix hashtag , by 46 april will go into a kickstarter fundraising campaign and ultimately into development .
` we 've seen the great british designers of tomorrow create smart and simple solutions to real life everyday emergencies , ' said paul smyth , co-founder of makerversity .
` through the direct line everyday fix event , we 've been able to extend our role as " fixers " and work with some unique creative talent to produce a fantastic shortlist of exciting prototypes that start to solve the nation 's everyday emergencies , ' added john shaw , head of r&d and innovation at direct line .
of the products that did n't make the cut , one was a helmet with ` bone conduction headphones ' that gave you directions while cycling without impairing your ability to hear the environment around you .
another was a parking pin that you could leave in a space , which would then alert you when the space was free , if you could n't find somewhere to park .
and as another solution to your phone running out of battery , one team designed an app that lets you nominate people to receive your messages when your phone dies .
products that did n't make the final shortlist included the parking pin , shown .
you could leave this in a parking space , and it will alert you when the space is free , so you can park your car
the relay app , shown , would let you nominate people to receive your messages when your phone dies
and the ` hat nav ' was a smart helmet that used ` bone conduction headphones ' to give you directions while cycling without impairing your ability to hear the environment around you
summary:
The passage discusses a competition called #everydayfix, organized by Direct Line and London-based design company Makerversity. The competition aims to find solutions for common everyday emergencies, as voted by a survey of 2,000 people. The top emergency was identified as not being able to sleep.

Three products were shortlisted from the competition:
1. Snooze: An alarm clock that connects with your phone and silences notifications to ensure a good night's sleep.
2. Forget Me Lock: A device that fastens on a key and swivels green to show the door is open and red to signify it's locked, helping people remember if they have locked their front door.
3. Nipper: The world's smallest mobile phone charger, designed to help people who run out of battery while they are out and about.

People can vote for their favorite product by retweeting tweets about Snooze, Forget Me Lock, or Nipper on Twitter. The product with the most retweets will go into a Kickstarter fundraising campaign and ultimately into development by April 2023

whichever tweet has the most retweets , with the #everydayfix hashtag , by 46 april will go into a kickstarter fundraising campaign and ultimately into development .

summary: A company, Direct Line, is running a competition called #EverydayFix, where groups designed products to solve common everyday emergencies. The top ten emergencies, based on a survey of 2,000 people, included not being able to sleep, losing keys, and running out of battery. The winning product, 'Snooze,' is an alarm clock that connects with your phone and silences notifications to ensure a good night's sleep. Another product, 'Forget Me Lock,' is a device that attaches to a key and indicates if the front door is locked or not. The third product, 'Nipper,' is a small mobile phone charger that can use any household battery. The winning product will be made into an actual product through a Kickstarter campaign, with the winner determined by the most retweets using the #EverydayFix hashtag by April 46th.

summary:
Here's a concise summary of the core information in the passage:

A company called Direct Line is running a competition called #everydayfix to address common everyday problems. They surveyed 2,000 people to identify top "everyday emergencies" and asked design groups to create prototype solutions. Three finalists were chosen:

1. Snooze: An alarm clock that silences phone notifications for better sleep.
2. Forget Me Lock: A device that attaches to keys and shows if a door is locked or unlocked.
3. Nipper: A small mobile phone charger that uses household batteries.

People can vote for their favorite product on Twitter, and the winner will be funded through a Kickstarter campaign and developed into an actual product. Other interesting prototypes that didn't make the final cut include a smart cycling helmet with navigation, a parking space finder, and an app to redirect messages when your phone dies.

The competition aims to showcase innovative solutions to common problems and extend Direct Line's role as "fixers" in everyday life.

The top three prototypes are: 'Snooze', an alarm clock that mutes phone notifications for better sleep; 'Forget Me Lock', a device indicating a locked door with a colour change; and 'Nipper', a tiny phone charger powered by household batteries. The winner will be chosen via Twitter retweets and funded through Kickstarter.

the products were designed as part of the direct line everyday fix design makeathon .

losing an important paper or document ( 33 per cent )
nowhere to park ( 32 per cent )

discovering you are out of toilet roll whilst on the loo ( 30 per cent )
dealing with machine operated customer service ( 26 per cent )
forgetting your bank card when paying for an item ( 25 per cent )
* how many people thought this was a problem
in the survey of 2,000 people , the top emergency was not being able to sleep .
so a group called instruments designed a product called ` snooze ' , an alarm clock which connects with your phone and silences any notifications to ensure a good night 's sleep .
to deal with not remembering if you had locked your door , onn studio created the forget me lock - a device to reassure you that you have locked the front door .
it fastens on the key and swivels green to show the door is open , and red to signify it 's locked .
this means that even when out or about , you can find out if your door is locked or not .
another group designed nipper - the world 's smallest mobile phone charger according to its creators , impulse .
any household battery can be used as its energy source , with two terminals attaching either side and then connecting to your phone to provide a boost .
direct line is running a competition on twitter where you can vote for your favourite of these three products by retweeting tweets about snooze , forget me lock or nipper .
the forget me lock is coloured green and red and fastens on a key .
when the key is turned in a lock it swivels green to show the door is open , and red to signify it 's locked .

in the survey of 2,000 people , the top emergency was not being able to sleep .
so a group called instruments designed a product called snooze , shown , an alarm clock which connects with your phone and silences any notifications to ensure a good night 's sleep
whichever tweet has the most retweets , with the #everydayfix hashtag , by 46 april will go into a kickstarter fundraising campaign and ultimately into development .
` we 've seen the great british designers of tomorrow create smart and simple solutions to real life everyday emergencies , ' said paul smyth , co-founder of makerversity .
` through the direct line everyday fix event , we 've been able to extend our role as " fixers " and work with some unique creative talent to produce a fantastic shortlist of exciting prototypes that start to solve the nation 's everyday emergencies , ' added john shaw , head of r&d and innovation at direct line .
of the products that did n't make the cut , one was a helmet with ` bone conduction headphones ' that gave you directions while cycling without impairing your ability to hear the environment around you .
another was a parking pin that you could leave in a space , which would then alert you when the space was free , if you could n't find somewhere to park .

you could leave this in a parking space , and it will alert you when the space is free , so you can park your car
the relay app , shown , would let you nominate people to receive your messages when your phone dies
and the ` hat nav ' was a smart helmet that used ` bone conduction headphones ' to give you directions while cycling without impairing your ability to hear the environment around you
summary: Direct Line, a UK insurance company, ran a competition called #EverydayFix to address common daily emergencies. They surveyed 2,000 people to identify top issues like not being able to sleep, losing keys, and running out of phone battery. Based on the survey results, design teams created prototypes such as the Snooze alarm clock, Forget Me Lock, and Nipper mobile charger. The public can vote for their favorite product via Twitter; the winning design will be funded through a Kickstarter campaign. Other ideas like a parking pin and a relay app for messaging when phones die were also considered but didn't make the final shortlist.

source:
have you ever panicked about whether you locked the front door , been woken by a facebook notification or desperately needed a phone charger ?
to deal with these sorts of everyday emergencies , one company has designed a range of prototype products .
you can vote on which one is your favourite - and the winner will be made into an actual product , funded through a kickstarter campaign .
leeds-based direct line is running a competition called #everydayfix .
they asked groups to design products to deal with common problems .
these include forgetting to lock the door , which one company hopes to solve with their forget me lock prototype , shown
the products were designed as part of the direct line everyday fix design makeathon .
they asked people to pick their top ten ` everyday emergencies ' - things that caused them an undue amount of stress in their daily lives .
groups from london-based design company makerversity were then asked to design products that could alleviate certain emergencies - and three were picked for a shortlist .
not being able to sleep ( 46 per cent * )
losing your keys ( 37 per cent )
being stuck in traffic when already late ( 35 per cent )
losing an important paper or document ( 33 per cent )
nowhere to park ( 32 per cent )
printer not working when you need to print something ( 31 per cent )
running out of battery on your phone whilst out ( 31 per cent )
discovering you are out of toilet roll whilst on the loo ( 30 per cent )
dealing with machine operated customer service ( 26 per cent )
forgetting your bank card when paying for an item ( 25 per cent )
* how many people thought this was a problem
in the survey of 2,000 people , the top emergency was not being able to sleep .
so a group called instruments designed a product called ` snooze ' , an alarm clock which connects with your phone and silences any notifications to ensure a good night 's sleep .
to deal with not remembering if you had locked your door , onn studio created the forget me lock - a device to reassure you that you have locked the front door .
it fastens on the key and swivels green to show the door is open , and red to signify it 's locked .
this means that even when out or about , you can find out if your door is locked or not .
another group designed nipper - the world 's smallest mobile phone charger according to its creators , impulse .
any household battery can be used as its energy source , with two terminals attaching either side and then connecting to your phone to provide a boost .
direct line is running a competition on twitter where you can vote for your favourite of these three products by retweeting tweets about snooze , forget me lock or nipper .
the forget me lock is coloured green and red and fastens on a key .
when the key is turned in a lock it swivels green to show the door is open , and red to signify it 's locked .
another group designed nipper - the world 's smallest mobile phone charger according to its creators , impulse .
any household battery can be used as its energy source , with two terminals attaching either side and then connecting to your phone to provide a boost
the nipper device ( shown ) is designed to help people who run out of battery while they are out and about
in the survey of 2,000 people , the top emergency was not being able to sleep .
so a group called instruments designed a product called snooze , shown , an alarm clock which connects with your phone and silences any notifications to ensure a good night 's sleep
whichever tweet has the most retweets , with the #everydayfix hashtag , by 46 april will go into a kickstarter fundraising campaign and ultimately into development .
` we 've seen the great british designers of tomorrow create smart and simple solutions to real life everyday emergencies , ' said paul smyth , co-founder of makerversity .
` through the direct line everyday fix event , we 've been able to extend our role as " fixers " and work with some unique creative talent to produce a fantastic shortlist of exciting prototypes that start to solve the nation 's everyday emergencies , ' added john shaw , head of r&d and innovation at direct line .
of the products that did n't make the cut , one was a helmet with ` bone conduction headphones ' that gave you directions while cycling without impairing your ability to hear the environment around you .
another was a parking pin that you could leave in a space , which would then alert you when the space was free , if you could n't find somewhere to park .
and as another solution to your phone running out of battery , one team designed an app that lets you nominate people to receive your messages when your phone dies .
products that did n't make the final shortlist included the parking pin , shown .
you could leave this in a parking space , and it will alert you when the space is free , so you can park your car
the relay app , shown , would let you nominate people to receive your messages when your phone dies
and the ` hat nav ' was a smart helmet that used ` bone conduction headphones ' to give you directions while cycling without impairing your ability to hear the environment around you
summary:
Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Direct Line, a Leeds-based company, has launched a competition called #everydayfix to design products that solve common everyday emergencies. A survey of 2,000 people identified the top 10 everyday emergencies, including not being able to sleep, losing keys, and running out of phone battery. Three prototype products were shortlisted: Snooze (an alarm clock that silences notifications), Forget Me Lock (a device that reassures you that your door is locked), and Nipper (a small mobile phone charger that uses household batteries). The public can vote for their favorite product on Twitter, and the winner will be made into an actual product through a Kickstarter campaign. The competition aims to find innovative solutions to everyday problems and showcase the creative talent of designers.

summary: Direct Line, an insurance company, held a competition called #everydayfix to design products that solve common everyday problems.  The top ten problems identified were: not being able to sleep, losing keys, being stuck in traffic, losing important documents, nowhere to park, printer not working, running out of phone battery, running out of toilet paper, dealing with automated customer service, and forgetting your bank card.  Three products were chosen as finalists: Snooze, an alarm clock that silences phone notifications to ensure a good night's sleep; Forget Me Lock, a device that fastens to a key and turns green when the door is open and red when it is locked; and Nipper, a small mobile phone charger that uses household batteries.  The winner of the competition, determined by the most retweets on Twitter with the #everydayfix hashtag, will be funded through a Kickstarter campaign.

summary: A company called Direct Line has designed a range of prototype products to deal with everyday emergencies. They asked groups to design products to solve common problems, such as forgetting to lock the door. The top three emergencies identified were not being able to sleep, losing keys, and being stuck in traffic when already late. The prototypes include an alarm clock called "Snooze" that silences notifications to ensure a good night's sleep, a device called "Forget Me Lock" that shows if the front door is locked or not, and a small mobile phone charger called "Nipper" that can be powered by any household battery. Direct Line is running a competition on Twitter where people can vote for their favorite product, and the winner will be made into an actual product funded through a Kickstarter campaign.

summary: A Leeds-based company, Direct Line, is running a competition called #everydayfix to address common daily emergencies through innovative product designs. Participants were asked to identify their top ten everyday problems, and groups from the London-based design company Makerversity created solutions. Three prototypes were shortlisted: "Snooze," an alarm clock that silences phone notifications to aid sleep; "Forget Me Lock," a device that indicates whether a door is locked; and "Nipper," a small mobile phone charger using household batteries. The public can vote for their favorite product on Twitter, and the winner will be funded through a Kickstarter campaign. Other notable but unselected designs included a smart helmet for cyclists, a parking pin, and an app for message forwarding when a phone dies.
